(Ord. No. 72-20, 11-9-72) 
Sec. 6-6-4. - Stagnant, foul and offensive water. 
    If any person shall permit or allow any stagnant, foul or offensive water to remain upon any lot or premises or under the floor of any building owned or occupied by such person, he shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and each day foul or offensive water is allowed or permitted to remain upon the lot or premises or under the floor of any building owned or occupied by such person shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 72-20, 11-9-72) 
Sec. 6-6-5. - When city shall abate. 
    Whenever any nuisance as herein defined is found to exist in any place in the city or outside the city limits within a distance of 5,000 feet therefrom, for the removal or abatement of which no person can be held liable under the provisions hereof; it shall be the duty of the chief of police or health officer to remove, abate or destroy the same at the expense of the city. 
(Ord. No. 72-20, 11-9-72) 
Sec. 6-6-6. - Waste of water; penalty. 
(a)  Waste unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits to waste water. 
(b)  Waste defined. For the purpose of this chapter, "waste" is defined as causing, suffering or permitting a flow of water from a water main to run into any river, creek or other natural watercourse or drain, superficial or underground channel, bayou, or into any sanitary or storm sewer, any street, road or highway or upon the lands of another person, or upon public lands, without first having obtained the maximum degree of beneficial use thereof. 
(c)  Maximum degree of beneficial use. For the purpose of this chapter, the term "maximum degree of beneficial use" is defined, and shall be construed to mean, the use of water under means and by methods of conservation as hereinafter in this chapter set out so that only that amount of water as is actually and necessarily required for a specific purpose be used by the consumer or inhabitant. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be liable to the penalty provided for a violation of this Code. 
(e)  Repeated violations. At locations of repeated or continued violations, the inspection division of the department of public works shall have the authority to order the city water board to discontinue the water supply to the violator. The violation of this section shall be a nuisance which may be abated and enjoined by the city. 
(5-10-55) 
CHAPTER 7. - CONDUCT ON BUSINESS PREMISES 

Sec. 6-7-1. - Definitions. 
    Grocery store. Includes convenience food stores, supermarkets and businesses whose primary business is the sale of foodstuffs and beverages for off-premises consumption. 
    Legally parked motor vehicle. Any motorized vehicle that is stopped or parked in a designated parking area on a business premises and the operator or the occupants are patronizing the business. 
    Owner or operator. The person who owns or manages a business premises. This does not include an employee with no managerial capacity, but an employee's action may be sanctioned by an employer. 
    Premises. That area including structure, canopies, driveways, loading areas, accessory buildings, undeveloped land in the same lot and block of an individual business, parking lot and in the case of communal parking, in a shopping center all parking area that is immediately available to any person or persons using or patronizing a business. (The parking area of a communal parking lot, public or private, shall be determined by the use afforded to the public by the owner or owners in the normal course of their business operations, as in the case of two separately owned public parking lots where the owners normally share and encourage their patrons to share each other's parking facilities; and those areas which would be commonly defined and understood as shopping center parking lots.) 
(Ord. No. 84-52, 9-13-84) 
Sec. 6-7-2. - Prohibited acts and conditions. 
    After the effective date of this chapter, the following acts or conduct of any person or persons entering or upon the premises of any restaurant, drive-in restaurant, pool hall, amusement center, movie theater, grocery store or any other business providing goods and/or services to the public are hereby declared to be unlawful: 
(1)  To enter such premises in a motor vehicle of any kind and using such premises for cruising, racing, as a shortcut to another street, accelerating or racing the motor of a vehicle from a sudden start or stop as to cause a loud noise in a manner calculated to disturb the person or persons present, bring a motor vehicle to a sudden stop or start or blowing the horn when no necessity for the protection of the driver or personal property exists and in a manner calculated to disturb the person or persons present, to annoy or endanger any person or persons or other vehicle or vehicles lawfully on such premises. 
(2)  For three or more person to congregate on the premises and linger or loiter at any location on the premises of any restaurant, drive-in restaurant, pool hall, amusement center, movie theater, grocery store or any other business providing goods and/or services to the public, other than persons legally in the store or facility or in a legally parked motor vehicle. It shall be the duty of the premises owner or operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs bearing the following legend: "Cruising or Congregating or Loitering is Unlawful. City of Weatherford Ordinance #84-52." 
(3)  For any person to roller skate, roller blade, skateboard or use or ride a similar device(s) on the premises. It shall be the duty of the premises owner or operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs bearing the following legend: "Use of roller skates, roller blades, skate boards or similar devices on these premises is unlawful. City of Weatherford Ordinance #99-45". 
(d)  To enter upon the premises of any restaurant, drive-in restaurant, pool hall, amusement center, movie theater, grocery store or any other business providing goods and/or services to the public and consume any alcoholic beverage on said premises or possess alcoholic beverages for immediate consumption on said premises. An alcoholic beverage means alcohol and any beverage containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume which is capable of use for beverage purposes, either alone or when diluted. 
(1)  Possession of any alcoholic beverage in an open container is prima facie evidence of the intent to consume it immediately. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the premises owner or operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs bearing the following legend. "No alcoholic beverages on premises. City of Weatherford Ordinance #84-52". 
(Ord. No. 84-52, 9-13-84; Ord. No. 99-45,  1, 2, 12-28-99) 
Sec. 6-7-3. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than $200.00 for each offense. Each and every day the violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 84-52, 9-13-84) 
CHAPTER 8. - DISTURBING THE PEACE 

Sec. 6-8-1. - Improper noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, aid, countenance or assist in making any improper noise, disturbance, breach of the peace, or diversion in the streets or elsewhere within the corporate limits. All persons who shall collect in crowds or bodies for unlawful purposes, to the annoyance of citizens, travelers or others shall severally be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-2. - Improper language. 
    Any person who shall, within the corporate limits, disturb the peace of others by violent, offensive or tumultuous conduct or behavior, or by loud or unusual noise, or who shall use boisterous or obscene language in the streets or other public places, or who shall use any abusive, threatening or indecent language towards another shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-3. - Provoking a breach of the peace. 
    Any person who shall, within the corporate limits, use any abusive, insulting, obscene, profane or threatening language, or any threatening gestures toward another in a manner calculated to bring about or provoke a breach of the peace, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-4. - Disturbing residents. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go into or near any public place, or into or near any private house, and to use loud and vociferous language, or swear, or curse, or yell, or shriek, or expose his person, or rudely display any pistol or other deadly weapon in a manner calculated to disturb the inhabitants of such public place or private house, the same being within the corporate limits. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-5. - Assault and battery. 
    Any person who shall, within the corporate limits, commit an assault, or an assault and battery, upon the person of another shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-6. - Fighting. 
    If any two or more persons shall fight together in a public place within the corporate limits they shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-7. - Shooting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any gun, pistol or firearm of any description on or across any public square, street, or alley within the corporate limits. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-8. - Horse racing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to run, or be engaged or in any way concerned in running any horse race in, along or across any public square, street or alley within the corporate limits. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-9. - False fire alarm. 
    Any person who shall knowingly give or make a false alarm of fire within the corporate limits shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-10. - Duty of owner. 
    It shall be the duty of every keeper of a barroom, restaurant, grog shop, the proprietor or keeper of all billiard tables, nine or ten pin alleys, and of every person keeping a public or private house of any kind within the city to keep good order within the same, and to prevent all persons who may be therein from disturbing the peace and tranquility of the inhabitants of the neighborhood or inhabitants or passersby of said public place, by cries, vociferous songs, profane or indecent language, or by any noise or disturbance whatever, and it shall be unlawful for any person to permit or to fail to put a stop to any such disorder, noise, disturbances, or profane or indecent language, within his or her house. 
(2-2-88) 
Sec. 6-8-11. - Disturbing public assembly. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to disturb, insult, or molest any public meeting assembled for any legitimate purpose by riotous or disorderly conduct, or by rude or indecent behavior, or profane, obscene or indecent language, or by any noise, tumult, loud cries, blowing horns, singing, or by any other noise or disturbance whatsoever, with the intent or purpose to harass, vex or annoy or interfere with such meeting. 
(2-2-88) 
CHAPTER 9. - MORALS AND DECENCY 

Sec. 6-9-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-20, adopted April 28, 1987, repealed  6-9-1 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to indecent exposure. 
Sec. 6-9-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-20, adopted April 28, 1987, repealed 6-9-2 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to pornographic material. 
Sec. 6-9-3. - Drunkenness. 
    Any person who shall get drunk or be found in a state of intoxication in any public place within the corporate limits shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(4-15-84) 
Sec. 6-9-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-45, adopted Dec. 1986, repealed  6-9-4 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to sleeping in streets. 
Sec. 6-9-5. - Loitering at night. 
    Any person who shall within the limits of the city be found loitering around or concealed at night or other inappropriate time, in or about any building or private residence premises not his own, under suspicious circumstances, and not being able to give a satisfactory account thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(4-15-84) 
Sec. 6-9-6. - Arrest without warrant. 
    Arrest without warrant may be made by the chief of police or any other police officer of the city, when offenses against the laws or provisions of this Code are committed in their presence or where persons are found in suspicious places, and under circumstances which reasonably show that such persons have been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threaten to or are about to commit some offense against the law. 
(Ord. No. 62-12, 7-12-61) 
Sec. 6-9-7. - Airplane glue, sale of. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein no person shall sell, offer for sale, deliver or give to any individual under the age of 17 years any glue or cement commonly known as model airplane glue, plastic cement, household cement or any other similar substance or product if such glue or cement or similar product contains one or more of any of the following volatile solvents: 
    Acetone 
    Cyclohexanone 
    Ethyl acetate 
    Hexane 
    Isopropanol 
    Methyl cellosolve acetate 
    Methyl ethyl ketone 
    Methyl isobutyl ketone 
    Toluene 
    Toluol 
    Trichlorethylene 
    Trichloroethane 
    The above provisions relative to the sale, offer for sale, delivery or gift of certain glues and cements shall not apply where said glue or cement is sold, delivered or given simultaneously with and as a part of a kit used for the construction of model airplanes, model boats, model automobiles, model trains or other similar models. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to inhale any glue or cement containing one or more of the above listed volatile solvents or the fumes or vapors thereof with the intent of obtaining intoxicating or narcotic effect thereby. Whenever any person shall sniff and/or inhale such glues, ce ments or the fumes or vapors thereof, without being actively engaged in assembling, constructing or repairing models or other household articles by use of said glue or cement at the time of said sniffing or inhaling, it shall be prima facie evidence in the trial of any case alleging violation of this section that such sniffing and/or inhalation was done with the intent of obtaining intoxicating or narcotic effects. 
(Ord. No. 67-5, 6-29-67) 
CHAPTER 10. - ABANDONED CONTAINERS 

Sec. 6-10-1. - Unlawful act. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or abandoned building structure or dwelling under his control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has a door or lid, snaplock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing said door or lid, snaplock or other locking device. 
(Code 1962) 
CHAPTER 11. - AIR GUNS, FIREARMS 

Sec. 6-11-1. - Definitions. 
    Whenever the term "firearms" is used in this chapter, the term shall mean any instrument used in the propulsion of shot, shell or bullets or other harmful objects by the action of gunpowder exploded within it, or by the action of compressed air within it, or by the power of springs and including what are commonly known as air rifles and BB guns. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-11-2. - Concealed weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry concealed upon his person any brass knuckles, revolver, pistol, dagger, stiletto or other deadly weapon. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-11-3. - Discharge of firearms prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge firearms of any kind or description within the limits of the municipality; provided however, that this shall not apply to police officers in the discharge of their duties. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-11-4. - Exceptions; permits. 
    The governing body may at any time, upon receipt of proper application, grant permits to shooting galleries, gun clubs and others for shooting in fixed localities and under specified rules. Such permits shall be in writing attested by the city secretary conforming to such requirements as the governing body shall demand, and the permit thus issued shall be subject to revocation at any time by action of the governing body. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-11-5. - Specified rules for indoor firing ranges in fixed localities. 
(a)  Division 1. Generally 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building inspection division means that division within the planning and development department that is assigned the responsibility of enforcement of the construction code. 
    Indoor firing range means an indoor room, place or enclosure, wherein the firing of firearms is permitted to practice marksmanship. 
(2)  Exemptions. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any firearms practice range or facility of any sort which: 
a.  Is owned and operated by the United States, the State of Texas or any department or political subdivision thereof; and 
b.  Is utilized exclusively for the purpose of training and qualifying peace officers and persons in training to become peace officers. 
(3)  General regulations. 
a.  No indoor firing range shall be constructed or operated within the city unless fully enclosed and the plans for such are submitted to the building inspection division. The indoor firing range shall comply with all provisions of the currently adopted construction code, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), National Rifle Association (NRA) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). Where these provisions are dissimilar, the most restrictive shall be followed. The recommendation of the chief of police shall be required as to the location of any indoor firing range. 
b.  The room, place or enclosure, wherein the discharge of firearms is to take place, shall comply with all provisions of this section and shall not be used for any other purpose whatsoever. 
c.  The floor, rear wall and side walls, to a point on a line with the firing position, shall be of bullet proof construction in accordance with the following specifications: 
1.  Not less than six-inch masonry or solid concrete; or 
2.  Wood stud and plaster walls or equivalent construction, faced with one inch boards, backed with one-quarter-inch steel plate. Floors and ceilings of joist construction shall be considered bullet proof. 
d.  All openings of any nature in the rear and side walls shall be protected with one-inch board backed by a one-quarter inch steel plate. 
e.  Open steel truss ceilings shall be protected by a one-quarter inch steel baffle plate inclined toward the firing position. The plate shall be as wide as the total width of the target and not less than five feet in depth, and shall be suspended from the bottom cord of the trusses to the intersection of two sight lines drawn from the elevation of the firearm at the prone firing position to the bottom of the furthest truss, and from the elevation of the firearm at the off-hand firing position to a point five feet above the floor at the target. Baffle plates less than 15 feet from the firing position shall be protected with one-inch boards. 
f.  Exposed steel girders less than 15 feet (horizontal or vertical) from the firing position shall be protected with one-inch boards. 
g.  In addition to the above protection, there shall be provided a one-quarter inch steel stop plate, directly in the rear of targets, extending not less than eight inches beyond the outer ring of the bull's-eye, and inclined towards the firing position at an angle of 45 degrees. The stop plate shall be housed, on sides and top, with corrugated sheet metal extending not less than one foot beyond the top edge of the plate. At the base of the inclined stop plate there shall be provided a sand box with not less than six inches of sand and of sufficient width so as to absorb all of the bullets ricocheted by the stop plate as fired from the firing position. 
h.  Vertical stop plates existing on October 23, 1957, will be accepted with the same regulations as is provided for inclined stop plates, except that the thickness of the stop plate shall be not less than 5/16 th of an inch and that the corrugated sheet metal housing shall extend not less than three feet beyond the face of the stop plate. 
i.  Entrance to that part of the licensed area situated between the firing position and targets shall be protected with 36-inch guard rails or equivalent protection. No person except the person in charge shall be permitted within the above described area during the progress of firing. 
j.  There shall be a separate drain leading to a collection tank to capture all water due to the potential of lead contamination. These tanks shall be emptied by a professional licensed to deal in hazardous materials, including lead and the water shall be disposed of in accordance with EPA and OSHA standards. 
k.  There shall be no outside discharge of firearms. All firearm discharge must remain within the authorized areas of a permitted, licensed indoor firing range. 
1.  There shall be rules of conduct established for the indoor firing range, posted in a prominent location with a warning that all users do so at their own risk. 
l.  An applicant for an indoor firing range may submit an alternative design that meets all the requirements of this section, provided such design is accompanied by a certificate by a fulltime practicing professional engineer, registered by the State of Texas, certifying that the facility will, if constructed in accordance with the applicant's plans and specifications, meet the construction and safety standards specified in this section. 
(4)  Stationary targets. Targets used at indoor firing ranges shall be of the stationary type or of a varying distance range type. All horizontally moving targets are prohibited. 
(5)  Certain weapons and ammunition prohibited at firing ranges. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or cause to be discharged within or upon any indoor firing range permitted under this chapter any rifle or pistol ammunition which is not authorized to be discharged at such indoor firing range by authority of this chapter and the permit issued to such indoor firing range. 
b.  Firearms may be discharged upon an indoor firing range permitted under this chapter, provided that the indoor firing range holds a valid permit issued under this section which authorizes the discharge thereof. The special permit shall be issued in the same manner in all respects as a regular indoor firing range permit under this chapter, except as provided in this section. 
c.  The applicant shall advise the building inspection division that he desires a permit and shall designate the maximum caliber and the most powerful standard pistol cartridge proposed to be fired at the indoor firing range. 
d.  The construction standards specified herein are minimum design criteria. The applicant shall cause the facility to be designed for the safe firing of the maximum caliber and cartridge proposed, and shall submit a certificate of a fulltime practicing professional engineer registered by the state that the facility will, if constructed in accordance with the applicant's plans and specifications, permit the safe firing thereof. 
e.  The applicant shall cause the facility to be designed so that, with all firing positions in use for the rapid fire discharge of the maximum proposed caliber and cartridge specified, the facility will not cause a noise disturbance across any real property boundary of the proposed site or within any public space or right-of-way. The applicant shall submit a certificate by a fulltime practicing professional engineer registered by the State of Texas who devotes at least 50 percent of his practice time to acoustical design certifying that the facility will, if constructed in accordance with the applicant's plans and specifications, meet the construction and noise standard specified in this subsection. 
f.  Prior to the issuance of a permit, the indoor firing range shall be inspected in test operation by an engineer designated by the director of planning and development to determine that the facility has been constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications proposed, and that safety and noise standards specified in subsections (c) and (d) of this section have in fact been met in the actual operation of the facility. 
g.  Upon such determination and compliance with all other provisions of this chapter, the director of planning and development shall issue a permit designating the maximum caliber and cartridge authorized to be fired upon the indoor firing range. 
h.  All design criteria, certificates and tests under this section shall be based upon the most powerful commercially manufactured cartridge loads for the pistol caliber and cartridge specified as produced by any manufacturer of handgun ammunition whose products are regularly sold in the city. Remanufactured or hand loaded ammunition shall be permitted to be fired, provided that it is not loaded in such a manner as to be more powerful than the maximum load allowed by the permit. 
(6)  Hours of operation. The operation of any indoor firing range between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. is hereby prohibited. 
(7)  Periodic inspections. Every indoor firing range for which a license has been issued under this chapter may be periodically inspected by the city manager or his/her designee, and such inspections shall be made and conducted at any time the same shall be deemed advisable in the opinion of the city manager or his/her designee and every indoor firing range shall be at all times open for inspection. All such inspections shall be subject to applicable constitutional limitations. 
(8)  Noise. 
a.  Within the city, no indoor firing range shall be permitted or operated in such a manner which causes the exterior noise level to exceed the ambient noise level by more than five decibels during daytime hours nor more than three decibels during nighttime hours. 
b.  This noise level shall be measured from, the closer of: 
1.  The property line; or 
2.  A point 100 feet, as measured from the closest exterior point of the building to any adjacent property owner's residence or place of business, whichever is closer. 
c.  The permit applicant shall be responsible for establishing and reporting to the city the ambient noise level of the proposed site before the issuance of an indoor firing range permit. 
d.  The indoor firing range shall be designed, engineered and constructed so as to ensure compliance with this section. All soundproofing shall comply with accepted industry standards and be subject to approval by the city's fire department. 
e.  The sound level meter used in the conducting noise evaluations shall meet the American National Standard Institute's standard for sound meters or an instrument and associated recording and analyzing equipment which will provide equivalent data. 
(9)-(15)  Reserved. 
(b)  Division 2. License 
(16)  Required. It shall be unlawful for a person to establish, maintain or operate, within the corporate limits of the city, an indoor firing range without having first secured a license to do so from the director of planning and development. Such license shall not be issued by the director of planning and development unless the person applying therefore has secured a certificate of occupancy from the building inspection division authorizing the occupancy of the premises for purposes of operating an indoor firing range. 
(17)  Application. Any person desiring a license required by this division shall make written application therefore to the planning and development department, on forms to be provided by the planning and development department. 
(18)  Inspection of premises. The director of planning and development shall cause an investigation and inspection to be made of any indoor firing range for which a license is desired, to determine if it is in compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(19)  Fee. The fee for a license under this division shall be $1,000.00 initially and $125.00 every year thereafter. Such fee shall be collected by the planning and development department before the issuance of such license or a renewal thereof. no refund of any license fee paid hereunder shall be made by the city for any cause whatsoever. 
(20)  Issuance. If the director of planning and development determines that an indoor firing range for which a license is applied for is in compliance with this chapter, the director of planning and development shall issue the license, upon payment of the required fee. 
(21)  Contents. A license issued under this division shall set forth the name and location of the indoor firing range covered by such license, the name or names of those persons to whom such license is issued and any other information that the director of planning and development may deem necessary. 
(22)  Display. A license issued under this division shall be placed and kept at all times in some open and prominent place within the indoor firing range. 
(23)  Expiration. All licenses issued under this division shall expire on the 31st day of December of the year for which issued. 
(24)  Transferability. Licenses issued under this division shall be deemed personal to the licensee and shall not be assigned or transferred to any other person. 
(25)  Prosecution and enforcement. No license granted under this division shall ever be held to bar a prosecution for violation of any other ordinance of this city, or to prevent the enforcement of any ordinance, or inhibit the exercise of powers and duties of any officer under the terms of any such ordinance. 
(26)  Appeal; notice of refusal. Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the director of planning and development in either granting or refusing a license to operate an indoor firing range shall have the right of an appeal to the city council by notifying the city council in writing within ten days after the decision of the director of planning and development of his appeal therefrom. Every person who is refused a license to operate an indoor firing range by the director of planning and development shall be notified in writing of the reasons for such refusal. 
(27)  Suspension or revocation. Any license issued under this division may be revoked on any of the following grounds: 
a.  Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or any rules and regulations either now or hereafter adopted pursuant hereto, or of any laws of the state. 
b.  Permitting, aiding or abetting the commission of any illegal act in or on the licensed premises. 
c.  Selling or permitting the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises. 
d.  Permitting any person under the influence of alcoholic beverages to use the facilities of the indoor firing range. 
e.  Acts, conduct or practices detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of any person in the city. 
(Ord. No. 345-2008-19,  2, 5-26-09) 
CHAPTER 12. - PLASTIC BAGS OR COVERINGS 

Sec. 6-12-1. - Definition. 
    The words "plastic coverings", "plastic bag", or "plastic package" when used in this chapter shall mean any covering, package or bag made of plastic material sufficiently thin and pliable to respond to static electricity created by contact with the human body to the extent that it clings to the human skin or body. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-12-2. - Warning required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession, or to deliver as a cover or wrapper, any plastic bag that is of sufficient size to fit over a child's head, or any bag which, when open has an opening larger than 25 square inches or a capacity of more than 125 cubic inches unless there is at all times clearly printed on such bag or covering, or on a paper attached to such bag or covering, words in letters at least one-quarter inch high as follows: 
WARNING. To avoid danger of suffocation keep this bag (or covering) away from babies and children. Do not use in cribs, beds, carriages or play pens. This is not a toy. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 6-12-3. - Certain bags a nuisance. 
    Any plastic bag, covering or package not carrying or accompanied by the printed warning as provided in section 6-12-2 of this chapter is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1962) 
CHAPTER 13. - CEMETERIES 

Sec. 6-13-1. - Cemeteries subject to chapter provisions. 
(a)  The following named cemeteries and burying grounds located within the corporate limits of the city, and subject to the jurisdiction of the city, are subject to the provisions of this chapter: 
(1)  City cemetery (also known as Greenwood Cemetery). Located on the south side of Front Street between North Elm and North Rusk Streets, and being north of Town Creek. 
(b)  The owner of any cemetery or burying ground within the city limits not designated in subsection (a)(1) of this section may render such cemetery or burying ground subject to the provisions of this chapter by the posting of a sign in conformity with the requirements in section 6-13-3 of this chapter. Upon the posting of a sign(s) in conformity with the requirements of section 6-13-3 of this chapter, all provisions of this chapter may be enforced in such cemetery or burying ground. 
(Ord. No. 89-35, 11-14-89) 
Sec. 6-13-2. - Official hours designated. 
    All cemeteries and burying grounds within the city, designated in subsection 6-13-1(a)1 of this chapter, or made subject to the provisions of this chapter pursuant to subsection 6-13-1(b) of this chapter, shall officially open for lawful use daily during the hours between sunrise and sunset. 
(Ord. No. 95-7, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 6-13-3. - Posting of official hours. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforceable upon the posting of a sign at each entrance to the cemetery or burying ground reading as follows: 
OFFICIAL VISITING HOURS. 
Daily, Sunrise to Sunset. 
(Ord. No. 95-7, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 6-13-4. - Offense. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he enters into, attempts to gain access into, or is present in a cemetery or burying ground before or after the officially designated and posted hours for such cemetery or burying ground. 
(b)  It is an exception to applicability of subsection (a) of this section that the person had obtained prior written consent from the owner of the cemetery or burying ground to be present upon the said premises at an hour other than the official hours of said cemetery or burying ground. 
(c)  It is an exception to applicability of subsection (a) of this section that the person is an employee of the owner of the cemetery or burying ground on the premises in furtherance of duties of his employment and at the direction of said employer. 
(Ord. No. 89-35, 11-14-89) 
Sec. 6-13-5. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine in an amount not less than $1.00 and not more than $500.00. Each and every day a violation hereof exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-35, 11-14-89) 
CHAPTER 14. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 6-14-1. - Definition. 
    Alcoholic beverage means alcohol or any beverage containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume that is capable of use for beverage purposes, either alone or when diluted. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 6-14-2. - Alcohol consumption prohibited in certain public places. 
    A person commits an offense if he consumes an alcoholic beverage within the following defined areas save and except all privately owned or leased/rented single-family or two-family residential property which shall include the immediate curtilage or yard of such single-family or two-family residential property: 
    AREA I. Being an area beginning at the east side of the courthouse, thence in an easterly direction along the NBL on Fort Worth Street (US 80) to the intersection of Fort Worth Street with South Elm Street; 
    Thence in a southerly direction along the EBL of South Elm Street to a point at the intersection of South Elm Street and Russell Street; 
    Thence approximately 28.75 ft. east along the SBL of Russell Street to a point 300 ft. from the centerline of South Main Street; 
    Thence south along a line parallel to and 300 ft. east of the centerline of South Main Street (FM 51/SH 171) to a point which said line intersects with the NBL of Interstate 20; 
    Thence west along the NBL of Interstate 20 to a point 300 ft. west of the centerline of South Main Street (FM 51/SH 171); 
    Thence north along a line parallel to and 300 ft. west of the centerline of South Main Street (FM 51/SH 171) to a point at which said line intersects with the SBL of West Anderson Street; 
    Thence west along the SBL of Anderson Street to the intersection of Anderson Street with the WBL of South Waco Street; 
    Thence north along the WBL of South Waco Street to the intersection of South Waco Street and the NBL of Palo Pinto Street (US 80); 
    Thence along the NBL of Palo Pinto Street east to the courthouse, also being the place of beginning. 
    AREA II. Being all of that property commonly referred to as the Weatherford Independent School District High School, including, but not limited to, the football/track areas, and all practice areas, the baseball areas and all parking lots. 
    AREA III. Being all of that area commonly referred to as College Park North and College Park South. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 6-14-3. - Commission of offense. 
    A person commits an offense if he consumes an alcoholic beverage while sitting in or on any vehicle or other conveyance whether moving or parked while said vehicle or convenience is located in the geographic areas as identified herein save and except privately owned or leased/rented single-family or two-family residential property which shall include the immediate curtilage or yard of such single-family or two-family residential property. Any residential use of property greater than two-family being within the geographic areas defined herein shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 6-14-4. - Suspension of requirements. 
    The city council hereby specifically reserves the right to suspend the requirements of this chapter for a specified period of time not to exceed 72 hours for public sanctioned events upon formal application to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 6-14-5. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this chapter is intended to prohibit or otherwise control: 
(1)  The manufacture, sale, distribution, transportation or possession of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  The area within any establishment licensed by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission for alcohol consumption on the premises. 
(3)  The interior of any building, public or private, where the consumption of alcohol would not otherwise be a violation of the laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Sec. 6-14-6. - Penalty. 
    A person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, will be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 92-1, 1-14-92) 
Title VII - FIRE REGULATIONS[1]
