    City means City of Weatherford, Texas, a municipal Corporation and shall include the Weatherford Municipal Utility System. 
    Combination protection means an assembly installed for point-of-use isolation in addition to a premises isolation assembly. 
    Contamination means the entry into or presence in a public water supply system of any substance which may be deleterious to health and/or the quality of the water. 
    Cross connection means any physical arrangement where a potable water supply is connected, directly or indirectly (actual or potential), with any other non-potable water system, used water system or auxiliary water supply, sewer, drain conduit, swimming pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, swamp (evaporative) coolers, air conditioner units, fire protection system, or any other assembly which contains, or may contain, contaminated water, sewage, or other liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water system as a result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel, or change-over assemblies, or other temporary or permanent assemblies through which, or because of which, backflow may occur are considered to be cross connections. 
    Customer service inspector or CSI means an individual who has fulfilled the requirements set out in TCEQ Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems, paragraph 290.46(j)(l), or as amended. 
    Degree of hazard means the low or high hazard classification that shall be attached to all actual or potential cross connections. 
    Director the person or appointed to that position, or their duly appointed deputy, agent, representative or designee and shall be vested with the authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
    Double check detector assembly or DCDA shall mean an approved assembly consisting of two approved double check valve assemblies, set in parallel, equipped with a meter on the bypass line to detect small amounts of water leakage or use. This unit must be purchased as a complete assembly. The assembly may be allowed on fireline water services in place of an approved double check valve assembly upon approval by the local water authority. 
    Double check valve backflow prevention assembly or double check assembly or double check or DC assembly or DC shall mean an assembly which consists of two independently-operating check valves which are spring-loaded or weighted. The assembly comes complete with a shut-off valve on each side of the checks, as well as test cocks to test the checks for tightness. 
    Health hazard means an actual or potential threat of contamination of a physical or toxic nature to the public potable water system or the consumer's potable water system that would be a danger to health. 
    High hazard means the classification assigned to an actual or potential cross connection that could allow a substance that may cause severe illness or death if a backflow is introduced into the potable water supply. 
    Inspector means a person who is a cross connection inspector recognized by the City of Weatherford. 
    Low hazard means the classification assigned to an actual or potential cross connection that could allow a substance that may be objectionable, but not hazardous to one's health, if allowed to backflow into the potable water supply. 
    Mobile units means any operation which may have the potential to introduce contaminants into a potable water system from a mobile source. These include, but are not limited to: carpet-cleaning vehicles, water-hauling vehicles, street-cleaning vehicles, liquid-waste vehicles, power-wash operations and pest-control vehicles. 
    Non-residential use shall include all uses not specifically included in "residential uses" as defined in this section. 
    Person means a natural person (individual), corporation, company, association, partnership, firm, limited liability, joint venture, joint stock company or association, and other such entities. 
    Plumbing code shall mean the City of Weatherford's currently adopted Edition of the Uniform Plumbing Code which may be amended from time to time by the City Council of the City of Weatherford, Texas. 
    Plumbing hazard means an internal or plumbing-type cross connection in a consumer's potable water system that may be either a polytonal or a contamination-type hazard. 
    Point-of-use isolation means the appropriate backflow prevention within the consumer's water system at the point at which the actual or potential cross connection exists. 
    Pollutional hazard means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or the potability of the public or consumer's potable water system, but which would not constitute a health or system hazard, as defined. The maximum degree of intensity of pollution to which the potable water system could be degraded under this definition would cause a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause minor damage to the system or its appurtenances. 
    Potable water supply means any water supply intended or used for human consumption or other domestic use. 
    Premise or premises means any piece of property to which water is provided, including, but not limited to, all improvements, mobile structures, and structures located on it. 
    Premises isolation or containment protection means the appropriate backflow prevention at the service connection between the public water system and the water user. 
    Pressure vacuum breaker assembly or PVB shall mean an approved assembly consisting of a spring-loaded check valve loaded to the closed position, an independently operating air inlet valve loaded to the open position, and installed as a unit with and between two resilient-seated shut-off valves, and with suitable connections for testing. It is designed to protect against back siphonage only. 
    Public water system or system shall mean any public or privately owned potable water system which supplies water for public domestic use. The system must meet all the health requirements set forth by the TCEQ. The system will include all services, reservoirs, facilities, and any equipment used in the process of producing, treating, storing, or conveying water for public consumption. 
    Reduced pressure detector check assembly or RPDC shall mean an approved assembly consisting of two approved reduced pressure backflow assemblies, set in parallel, equipped with a meter on the bypass line to detect small amounts of water leakage or use. This unit must be purchased as a complete assembly. The assembly may be allowed on "fire line" water services in place of an approved reduced pressure principle backflow assembly upon approval by the local water purveyor. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly or reduced pressure principle assembly or RP assembly or RP shall mean an assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically operated mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve, located between the check valves, and at the same time, below the first check valve. The assembly shall include properly located test cocks and tightly closing shut-off valves at each end of the assembly. 
    Residential use shall include single-family dwellings, duplexes, multiplex housing and apartments where the individual units are each on a separate meter or in cases where two or more units are served by one meter. 
    Service connection is the point-of-delivery at which the public water system connects to the private supply line or lateral. 
    SOP means "Standard Operating Procedure manual", written specifically for the City of Weatherford. 
    Spill-resistant vacuum breaker or SVB shall mean an assembly containing an independently operating, internally loaded check valve, and independently operating, loaded air-inlet valve, located on the discharge side of the check valve. The assembly is to be equipped with a properly located resilient-seated test cock, a properly located bleed/vent valve, and tightly closing, resilient-seated shut off valves attached at each end of the assembly. This assembly is designed to protect against a non-health hazard (i.e., pollutant) or, a health hazard (i.e., contaminant) under a back siphonage condition only. 
    System hazard means an actual or potential threat of severe danger to the physical properties of the public or consumer's potable water supply or of a pollution or contamination that would have a detrimental effect on the quality of the potable water in the system. 
    TCEQ means Texas Commission for Environmental Quality. 
    Thermal expansion means heated water that does not have the space to expand. 
    Used water means water supplied by a public water system to a water user's system after it has passed through the service connection. 
    Weatherford means the City of Weatherford, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(1), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-2. - Purpose. 
    Pursuant to Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Section 290.44 and 290.46, or as amended, it is the responsibility of the city to protect its drinking water supply by instituting and enforcing a cross connection program. The purpose of this chapter is to comply with the above-cited regulatory requirements, and to protect the water supply of the city from contamination or pollution due to any actual or potential cross connections. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(2), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-3. - Backflow prevention assembly requirements. 
(a)  A cross connection inspector employed by or under contract to the city shall determine the type and location of backflow prevention assembly to be installed within the city's water service area. The assembly shall be required in each of the following circumstances, but shall not be limited to the following circumstances: 
(1)  When the nature and extent of any activity at a premise, or the materials used in connection with any activity at a premise, or materials stored at a premise, could contaminate or pollute the potable water supply; 
(2)  When a premise has one or more cross connections as that term is defined in section 8-8-1; 
(3)  When internal cross connections are present that are not correctable; 
(4)  When intricate plumbing arrangements are present that make it impractical to ascertain whether cross connections exist; 
(5)  When a premise has a repeated history of cross connections being established or re-established; 
(6)  When materials are being used such that, if backflow should occur, a health hazard could result; 
(7)  When installation of an approved backflow prevention assembly is deemed by an inspector to be necessary to accomplish the purpose of these regulations; 
(8)  When an appropriate cross connection survey report form has not been filed with the director or his designee; and 
(9)  Where multi-story buildings or any buildings exist with a booster pump or elevated storage tank. 
(b)  Any used water return system shall be protected with an RP assembly. 
(c)  If a point-of-use assembly has not been tested or repaired as required by this chapter, the installation of a reduced pressure principle assembly (RP) shall be required at the service connection. 
(d)  If an inspector determines that additions or re-arrangements have been made to the plumbing system without the proper permits, as required by the city, premise isolation shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(3), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-4. - Retrofitting. 
    Retrofitting shall be required on all service connections where an actual or potential cross connection exists, and wherever else the director or his designee deems retrofitting necessary. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(4), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-5. - Mobile units. 
(a)  A person who owns and/or operates any vehicle that uses water from the city's public water system shall obtain a use permit from the director or his designee before accessing the public water system. The director or his designee may require an air gap, or a backflow assembly commensurate with the degree of hazard mounted either on the vehicle or piping. 
(b)  The failure of the owner and/or operator of the vehicle to comply with this chapter shall be grounds for the city to revoke any permit and/or license required under the City's Code of Ordinances, or as amended, to operate the vehicle and/or the business for which such vehicle is used. 
(c)  The director or his designee may deny a permit to any person who is not in compliance with this chapter, and/or who has a history of violating the requirements of this chapter. 
(d)  All assemblies used to protect the water supply, when using a mobile unit, must abide by the maintenance and testing sections of this chapter. 
(e)  If there is a conflict between this section of the chapter and the City's Code of Ordinances, or as amended, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(5), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-6. - Multiple service connections. 
    Any premises requiring multiple service connections for adequacy of supply and/or fire protection shall have a backflow prevention assembly at each service connection. The assembly shall be commensurate with the degree of the highest potential hazard and shall be the same model at each connection. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(6), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-7. - Plumbing code. 
    As a condition of water service, customers shall install, maintain, and operate piping and plumbing systems in accordance with the city's currently adopted edition of the uniform plumbing code. If there is a conflict between this chapter and the plumbing code, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(7), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-8. - Thermal expansion. 
    It is the responsibility of the property owner, and or the lessee, to eliminate the possibility of thermal expansion, if a closed system has been created by the installation of a backflow prevention assembly. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(8), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-9. - Pressure loss. 
    The city shall have no liability for any water pressure drop caused by the installation of a backflow prevention assembly shall not be the responsibility of the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(9), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-10. - Parallel installation. 
    Premises where non-interruption of water supply is critical shall be provided with two assemblies of the same type installed in parallel. They shall be sized in such a manner that either assembly will provide the minimum water requirements while the two together will provide the maximum water requirements. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(10), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-11. - Residential service connections. 
    Any residential property which has been determined to have an actual or potential cross connection and/or has violated the plumbing code in any way, shall be required to install an approved backflow prevention assembly in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(11), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-12. - Non-residential construction. 
(a)  In all new non-residential construction, there shall be installed an approved backflow prevention assembly at the service connection. The type of the assembly will be commensurate with the degree of hazard as determined by the inspector. 
(b)  When a non-residential building is constructed and the end use of such building is not determined, or could change, a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly (RP) shall be installed at the service connection to provide protection of the public water supply. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(12), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-13. - Fire systems. 
    An approved double check detector assembly (DCDA) shall be the minimum protection on all new fire sprinkler systems using piping material that is not approved for potable water use and/or that does not provide for periodic flow-through during each 24-hour period. A reduced pressure detector check assembly (RPDC) must be installed, if any solution other than the potable water can be introduced into the sprinkler system. Retrofitting on fire sprinkler systems will be required in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where improper maintenance has occurred; 
(2)  On all high hazard systems; and 
(3)  Wherever an inspector deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(13), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-14. - Irrigation systems. 
(a)  All irrigation systems, which currently have no backflow protection or systems installed after the effective date of this chapter, shall be required to meet all specifications pertaining to irrigation systems as stipulated by the TCEQ Chapter 290.44 and 290.46 code, and the currently adopted edition of the uniform plumbing code. In the event that there is a conflict between these codes and regulations, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(b)  All irrigation systems which do not currently meet the specifications as stipulated in this chapter, will be required to meet these specifications within one year of the effective date of this chapter [Jan. 9, 2001]. 
(c)  In the event an assembly is removed each year to protect against freezing, it must be tested immediately upon re-installation. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(14), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-15. - Contract customers. 
    In the event other water districts have a contract to receive water services from the City of Weatherford or provide water services to any premises within or outside of the city's limits, they shall have an active, on-going cross connection program approved by the director or his designee. The city reserves the right to require a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly (RP) or an air gap at the interconnect. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(15), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-16. - Temporary meters. 
    All temporary meters will be required to have adequate protection against backflow. The type of assembly will be commensurate with the potential degree of hazard. The city will provide a temporary meter with a backflow prevention assembly. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(16), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-17. - Customer service inspections. 
(a)  Pursuant to the TCEQ water system regulations, a customer service inspection for cross connection control shall be completed by the city prior to providing continuous water service in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  To a newly constructed facility or previously existing premises; 
(2)  After any material improvement to building(s) or premises; 
(3)  Any correction or addition to the plumbing of any facility or premises served by the city's public water system; and 
(4)  Whenever the director or his designee deems it necessary. 
(b)  Permanent water service shall not be supplied to a new construction facility(s) until the customer service inspection is completed. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(17), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-18. - Cross connection inspector. 
    Inspectors, performing cross connection control duties with the city, must be approved by the director or his designee, and shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Be employed by, or under contract to, the city; and 
(2)  Meet the requirements set forth in the city's SOP manual, or as amended. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(18), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-19. - Backflow prevention assembly tester. 
(a)  All backflow prevention assembly testers operating within the city shall be certified in accordance with all applicable regulations of TCEQ. No person shall operate as a backflow prevention assembly tester within the city without first being annually registered with the director or his designee of the city and having paid all fees associated with this registration. 
(b)  At the time of registration, recertification, and upon request of the director or his designee, each person certified as a backflow prevention assembly tester shall furnish evidence to show that he/she is insured and bonded to perform services on private property and has current licenses as required by the State of Texas and the city to perform the contemplated services. 
(c)  Persons certified as backflow prevention assembly testers shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Hold a TCEQ-approved certification; 
(2)  Successfully completed a confined-space entry training class; 
(3)  Agree to abide by all industry standards as related to safety; and 
(4)  Maintain general commercial liability insurance and automobile liability insurance with the following minimum limits: $300,000.00 per person and $300,000.00 per accident for bodily injury, and $300,000.00 per accident for property damage, or $300,000.00 if combined and the City of Weatherford shall be shown as an "Additional insured" on such policy or policies. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(19), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-20. - Certified backflow prevention assembly tester responsibilities. 
(a)  No certified backflow prevention assembly tester shall operate within the city without first registering with the director or his designee. 
(b)  A registration shall remain in effect provided: 
(1)  The backflow prevention assembly tester maintains eligibility for registration and certification as defined in this chapter; 
(2)  The backflow prevention assembly tester attends, and successfully completes, an eight hour recertification training course approved by the director or his designee and TCEQ, annually; 
(3)  The backflow prevention assembly tester's registration is not revoked by the director or his designee; 
(4)  The tester abides by the most stringent requirements of the city or TCEQ; and 
(5)  The tester renews his/her registration with the director or his designee annually. 
(c)  If a certification remains expired for a period of one year, the backflow prevention assembly tester may re-establish registration eligibility by showing proof that he/she has re-taken a TCEQ-approved backflow prevention assembly tester certification course. 
(d)  Each applicant for registration shall: 
(1)  Provide evidence to the director or his designee that the applicant has available the necessary tools and equipment to properly test backflow prevention assemblies; 
(2)  provide evidence to the director or his designee that the applicant has successfully completed "Permit Confined-Space Entry Training" as specified by OSHA in 29 CRF 1910.146, or as amended; and 
(3)  Identify all test gauges the applicant will use in testing backflow prevention assemblies. 
(e)  A registered backflow prevention assembly tester shall: 
(1)  File the serial numbers of each of his/her test gauges with the director or his designee; 
(2)  Annually, have each recorded test gauge tested for accuracy and calibrated to maintain a two percent accuracy factor; 
(3)  Perform competent and accurate tests of each backflow prevention assembly, as determined by the director or his designee; 
(4)  Submit complete reports thereof to the director or his designee; 
(5)  List registered serial numbers of test gauges on tests and maintenance reports prior to submitting them to the director or his designee; and 
(6)  Not change the design and/or operation characteristics of a backflow prevention assembly. 
(f)  The director or his designee may revoke a registration, if a determination is made that the backflow prevention assembly tester: 
(1)  Has made false, incomplete, or inaccurate assembly testing reports; 
(2)  Has used inaccurate gauges; 
(3)  Has used improper testing procedures; 
(4)  Is not adequately insured, as stipulated in this chapter; 
(5)  Is not in compliance with safety regulations; 
(6)  Has failed to register the serial numbers of his/her test gauges and/or failed to calibrate gauges annually, as required by this chapter; 
(7)  Has used an inappropriate certification number; 
(8)  Has allowed someone to use their certification number; 
(9)  Has violated any provision of this chapter; and 
(10)  Has failed to competently perform the required appropriate tests on assemblies. 
(g)  If it is determined that a registration is to be revoked, the backflow prevention assembly tester will receive a notice of revocation and will be given notice of a hearing date before a board appointed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(20), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-21. - Testing of assemblies. 
(a)  The director or his designee will inspect and test, or cause to be inspected and tested, all assemblies in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Immediately after installation; 
(2)  A minimum of once a year; 
(3)  Immediately after repair; and 
(4)  Whenever the assembly is relocated. 
(b)  Assemblies may be required to be tested more frequently, if the director or his designee deems necessary. 
(c)  All assembly testing shall be performed by a certified and registered backflow prevention assembly tester, in accordance with TCEQ-approved test procedures. 
(d)  It is the responsibility of the property owner to have all assemblies tested in accordance with this chapter. 
(e)  The city shall not be liable for damage to an assembly that occurs during testing. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(21), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-22. - Maintenance of assemblies. 
(a)  A person who owns, operates, or manages premises in which required backflow prevention assemblies are installed, shall maintain such assemblies in proper working order at all times, including repair as required. All maintenance and repair of assemblies shall be done in accordance with all applicable regulations of the TCEQ and this chapter. 
(b)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be maintained in a manner that allows them to be tested by a method that has been approved by TCEQ. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(22), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-23. - Installation requirements. 
(a)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in accordance with this chapter and all plumbing codes currently adopted by the city. To ensure their proper operation and accessibility, these requirements shall include: 
(1)  The property owner shall obtain the required plumbing permits prior to installation and shall have the assembly inspected by an inspector and as required by the plumbing code; 
(2)  Containment assemblies shall be installed at the point of delivery of the water supply, before any branch in the line, and on private property located just inside the boundary of the city's right-of-way and/or at the point of the cross connection; 
(3)  All assemblies shall be protected from freezing and other severe weather conditions; 
(4)  All assemblies shall be of a type and model approved by the director or his designee; 
(5)  All vertical installations shall be approved in writing by the director or his designee, prior to installation; 
(6)  All assemblies shall be readily accessible with adequate room for maintenance and testing. 
(7)  Assemblies installed inside of a building shall be readily accessible at all times; 
(8)  Assemblies installed five feet or higher above the floor shall be equipped with a rigidly and permanently installed scaffolding acceptable to the director or his designee and which also meets all applicable requirements set out by the State of Texas occupational safety and health laws; 
(9)  The property owner and/or lessee shall register all backflow prevention assemblies with the director or his designee; said registration shall consist of date of installation, manufacturer, model, serial number of the backflow prevention assembly, and initial test report; 
(10)  The property owner and/or lessee assumes all responsibility for leaks and/or damage caused, directly or indirectly, by the assembly; 
(11)  The property owner and/or lessee shall also ensure that any vault is kept reasonably free of silt and debris; 
(12)  Any enclosure used to protect assemblies will be one that appears on the list approved by the American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE); 
(13)  Bypass lines are prohibited; pipe fittings which could be used for connecting a bypass line shall not be installed; 
(14)  All assemblies larger than two inches shall have a minimum of 12 inches on the back side, 24 inches on the test cock side, and the relief valve opening shall be at least 12 inches plus nominal size of assembly above the floor, or highest possible water level; 
(15)  All assemblies two inches and smaller shall have at least a six-inch clearance on all sides; 
(16)  Headroom of six feet is required in vaults without a fully removable top; 
(17)  A minimum access opening of 24 inches is required on all vault lids; and 
(18)  Installation will follow the procedures set out in the city's SOP, or as amended. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(23), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-24. - Installation standards and specifications for reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly (RP). 
(a)  All RP assemblies will be tested in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Immediately upon installation; 
(2)  After repair; 
(3)  Upon relocation; 
(4)  At least annually; and 
(5)  More often, if deemed necessary by the director or his designee. 
(b)  RPs shall be utilized where a substance is handled that would be hazardous to the public health, if introduced into the potable water system. An RP is normally used in locations where an air gap is impractical. An RP is effective against both backsiphonage and backpressure. 
(c)  RPs shall be sized to provide an adequate supply of water and pressure for the premises being served. 
(d)  The assembly shall be readily accessible for testing and/or maintenance and shall be located in an area where water damage to buildings and/or furnishings will not occur from relief valve discharge. An approved air gap funnel assembly may be used to direct minor discharges away from the assembly; this air gap funnel assembly will not control flow in a continuous relief situation. Drain lines will need to accommodate full relief valve discharge flow. 
(e)  RP assemblies may be installed in a vault only if relieve valve discharge can be drained to daylight through a boresight type drain. The drain shall be of adequate capacity to carry the full-rated flow of the assembly and shall be screened on both ends. 
(f)  No part of a reduced pressure backflow prevention assembly shall be submerged in water or installed in a location subject to flooding. 
(g)  An approved air gap shall be located at the relief valve orifice of RP assemblies. 
(h)  Deviations from these specifications will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis by the director. Any deviations shall be prohibited without prior written approval of the director or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(24), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-25. - Reduced pressure detector check assembly (RPDC). 
    Reduced pressure detector check assemblies may be utilized in all installations requiring a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly and detector metering. RPDAs shall comply with the installation requirements applicable for reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies (RP). Both assemblies will need to be tested in accordance with the schedule set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(25), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-26. - Double check valve backflow prevention assembly (DC). 
(a)  All DC assemblies will be tested in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Immediately upon installation; 
(2)  After repair; 
(3)  Upon relocation; 
(4)  At least annually; and 
(5)  More often, if deemed necessary by the director or his designee. 
(b)  Double check assemblies may be utilized where a substance is handled that would be objectionable, but not hazardous to health, if introduced into the potable water system. 
(c)  DC assemblies shall be sized to provide an adequate supply of water and pressure for the premises being served. 
(d)  The DC assembly shall be readily accessible with adequate room for testing and maintenance. It may be installed below grade, providing all test cocks are fitted with brass pipe plugs. All vaults shall be well drained, constructed of suitable materials, and sized to allow for the minimum clearances established above. 
(e)  Vertical installations are allowed on sizes up to and including four inches that meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Internally spring-loaded check valves; 
(2)  Flow is upward through assembly; 
(3)  Manufacturer states their assembly can be used in a vertical position; and 
(4)  Approved by the director or his designee. 
(f)  Deviations from these specifications will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis by the director or his designee. No deviations shall be permitted without prior written approval of the director or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(26), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-27. - Double check detector assembly (DCDA). 
    Double check detector assemblies may be utilized in all installations requiring a double check assembly and detector metering. They shall comply with the installation requirements applicable for double check assemblies (DCs). Both assemblies will need to be tested in accordance with the schedule set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(27), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-28. - Pressure vacuum breaker assembly (PVB) and spill-resistant vacuum breaker (SVB). 
(a)  PVBs and SVBs may be utilized at point-of-use protection only and where a substance is handled that would be hazardous to health, if introduced into the potable water system. PVBs and SVBs protect against backsiphonage only and shall not be installed where there is potential for backpressure. 
(b)  The assembly shall be installed a minimum of 12 inches above the highest use outlet or overflow level downstream from the assembly. 
(c)  PVBs and SVBs shall not be installed in an area subject to flooding or where damage would occur from water discharge. 
(d)  The assembly shall be readily accessible for testing and maintenance, with a minimum clearance of 12 inches all around the assembly. 
(e)  PVBs and SVBs shall be located between 12 inches above the highest outlet but no higher than and 60 inches above ground level. 
(f)  All PVBs and SVBs must be tested in compliance with this chapter. 
(g)  Deviations from these specifications will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. No deviations shall be permitted without prior written approval of the director or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(28), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-29. - Atmospheric vacuum breaker (AVB). 
(a)  AVBs protect against backsiphonage only, and are prohibited where there is potential for backpressure. 
(b)  The assembly shall be installed a minimum of six inches above the highest use outlet or overflow level downstream from the assembly. 
(c)  Shut-off valves downstream from the assembly are prohibited. 
(d)  AVBs shall be allowed only for those applications where there is less than 12 hours per day continuous use. 
(e)  AVBs shall not be installed in an area subject to flooding or where damage may occur from water discharge. 
(f)  AVBs shall be allowed for point-of-use protection only in accordance with the currently adopted edition of the plumbing code. In some installations, AVBs may not be recognized as adequate protection by the director or his designee; therefore, additional protection will be required. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(29), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-30. - Air gap separation. 
(a)  Air gap separations provide maximum protection from backflow hazards and may be utilized at premises where a substance is handled that would be hazardous to health, if introduced into the potable water system. 
(b)  An air gap separation shall be at least twice the diameter of the supply pipeline, measured vertically above the top rim of the receiving vessel, and in no case, less than one inch. If the receiving vessel is against any side walls, ribs or similar obstructions, the air gap separation shall be three times the diameter. If the receiving vessel is near two intersecting walls, the air gap separation shall be four times the diameter. If splashing is a problem, tubular screens may be attached or the supply line may be cut at a 45 degree angle. The air gap distance is measured from the bottom of the angle. Hoses shall not be allowed. 
(c)  Air gap separations shall not be altered in any way, and shall be available for inspection at all times. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(30), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-31. - Responsibilities of owners and renters. 
    It is the responsibility of all persons, property owners and/or lessees to abide by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(31), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-32. - Access to premises. 
(a)  Every person provided water service by the City of Weatherford, directly or indirectly, shall permit the director or his designee to enter their premises and/or buildings for the purpose of inspecting pipes, fixtures and/or the manner in which the water is used to determine compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Refusal to grant access to the premises for an inspection by an inspector and/or the director or his designee will result in the immediate termination of service. Service will not be reestablished until such time that an inspection of the facility can be made. 
(c)  Any and all costs associated the termination of service shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner and/or lessee. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(32), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-33. - Right-of-way encroachment. 
(a)  No person shall install and/or maintain a backflow prevention assembly upon or within any right-of-way of the city, except as provided by this section. 
(b)  A backflow prevention assembly required by this chapter may be installed upon or within any right-of-way of Weatherford only if the property owner and/or lessee proves to the city, by clear and convincing evidence, that there is no other feasible location for installing the assembly and installing it in the right-of-way will not interfere with traffic and/or utilities. A property owner and/or lessee must obtain Weatherford's approval of the location, height, depth, enclosure, and other requisites of the assembly prior to its installation. 
(c)  Any assembly or portion of an assembly which extends above ground shall be located no closer than 18 inches to the face of the curb. 
(d)  A property owner and/or lessee shall, at the request of the city and at the property owner's and/or lessee's sole expense, relocate a backflow prevention assembly which encroaches upon any right-of-way of the city, when such relocation is necessary for street and/or utility construction and/or repairs, and/or for purposes of public safety. 
(e)  All of the city's codes and/or ordinances relevant to easement issues will be recognized by and incorporated into this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(34), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-34. - Emergency suspension of water service. 
(a)  The city may, without prior notice, suspend water service to any premises when such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened backflow which: 
(1)  Presents or may present, imminent and substantial danger to the environment or to the health or welfare of persons; and/or 
(2)  Presents, or may present, imminent and substantial danger to Weatherford's public water supply. 
(b)  As soon as practical after the suspension of service, the city shall notify the owner or person in charge of the premises of the suspension in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall order such person to correct the cross connection which allowed the backflow to occur. When time permits, the city shall also notify the property owner, lessee, or occupant, prior to suspending water service. 
(c)  If any person fails to comply with an order, the city may take such steps as the city deems necessary to prevent, and/or minimize, damage to the public water supply and/or to minimize danger to persons. 
(d)  The city shall not reinstate suspended services until the person: 
(1)  Presents clear and convincing proof, satisfactory to the director or his designee, that the backflow has been eliminated and its cause determined and corrected; 
(2)  Pays the city for all costs the city incurred in responding to the backflow and/or threatened backflow; and 
(3)  Pays the city for all costs the city will incur in reinstating service. 
(e)  A person whose service has been suspended under this section may appeal the suspension of service provided the appeal is made in accordance with the City of Weatherford's SOP, or as amended, within ten days of notice of the suspension. 
(f)  A person is in violation of this chapter, if the person reinstates water service to premises suspended pursuant to this section without the prior approval of the director. 
(g)  The city may obtain a lien against the property to recover its response, abatement, and remediation costs. 
(h)  The remedies provided by this section are in addition to any other remedies set out in this chapter. The city's exercise of the remedy provided in this section shall not be a bar against, nor a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a violator. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(34), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-35. - Non-emergency termination of water service. 
(a)  The city may terminate the water supply of any water user who: 
(1)  Refuses the director's or his designee reasonable access to the water user's premises for the purpose of inspection; 
(2)  Hinders and/or denies the director or his designee access to backflow prevention assemblies; 
(3)  Fails to install a reduced pressure principle assembly as required by this chapter; 
(4)  Fails to install and/or maintain backflow prevention assemblies in compliance with this chapter; or 
(5)  Fails to install, maintain, and/or operate their piping and plumbing systems in accordance with the currently adopted edition of the plumbing code. 
(b)  The director or his designee may notify a water user of the proposed termination of its water supply. The water user may petition the director for a reconsideration and hearing in accordance with the City of Weatherford's SOP, or as amended. 
(c)  The remedies provided by this section are in addition to any other remedies set out in this chapter. The city's exercise of the remedy provided in this section shall not be a bar against, nor a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a violator. 
(d)  The director or his designee shall not reinstate suspended services until the person: 
(1)  Presents clear and convincing proof, satisfactory to the director or his designee, that the backflow has been eliminated and its cause determined and corrected; 
(2)  Pays the city for all costs the city incurs in responding to the backflow and/or threatened backflow; and 
(3)  Pays the city for all costs the city will incur in reinstating service. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(35), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-36. - Cost and expense of compliance. 
    The cost and expense of complying with this chapter shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner and/or lessee. These costs and expenses include, but are not limited to, purchasing, installation, testing and/or repair of the assembly. These costs and expenses shall also include, but are not limited to, point-of-use and premises isolation assemblies. The property owner and/or lessee shall reimburse the City of Weatherford for any and all costs and expenses incurred by the city in enforcing this chapter (the "reimbursement costs"). The reimbursement costs shall be assessed in the property owner's and/or lessee's current water bill and collected in accordance with the city's current procedures, or as amended. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  I(36), 1-9-01) 
Sec. 8-8-37. - Penalty provision. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or business entity violating this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a sum not exceeding $2,000.00. Each continuing day's violation under this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this chapter shall not preclude Weatherford from filing suit to enjoin the violation. Weatherford retains all legal rights and remedies available to the city pursuant to local, state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 00-51,  II, 1-9-01) 
CHAPTER 10. - ANTI-LITTER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 8-10-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases and their derivations shall have the following meanings: 
    Commercial handbill. Any printed or written matter, sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies or any matter of literature which: 
(1)  Advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing; or 
(2)  Directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or 
(3)  Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; or 
(4)  While containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Garbage. Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Household garbage. "Garbage", "refuse" and "rubbish" as defined herein and all other waste material generated by and accumulated from the daily activities of a household and excluding waste generated by and accumulated strictly during the course of recreational activities in a public place or public park. 
    Litter. "Garbage", "refuse", and "rubbish" as defined herein and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper. Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill. Any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Public place. Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, rights of way, or other public ways; any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings; and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
    Refuse. All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish. Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including, but not limited to, paper and paper products, wrappings, cardboard and cardboard signs, tin, aluminum and other metals, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87; Ord. No. 89-14, 7-11-89) 
Sec. 8-10-2. - Throwing or depositing litter in public places prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in those receptacles required in section 8-2-2 of this title or in the city dump as provided in section 8-2-10 of this title. 
(b)  No person shall throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, household garbage in a publicly maintained receptacle located in a public place within the city. 
(c)  It shall be a defense to prosecution under subsection (b) of this section that, at the time of the depositing of the household garbage, the public receptacle was not marked "City of Weatherford-Not for Household Garbage". 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87; Ord. No. 89-14, 7-11-89) 
Sec. 8-10-3. - Throwing or depositing litter upon private property prohibited. 
    No person shall throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, litter in or upon any private property occupied, unoccupied or vacant within the city, whether such property is owned by the person or not. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-4. - Manner of placing litter in receptacles. 
    Persons placing litter in receptacles therefor shall do so in a manner so as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or any other public place, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-5. - Sweeping into gutters prohibited. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the city, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free from litter. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-6. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit in any manner whatsoever, any litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-7. - Litter in parks. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit any litter in any park within the city except in receptacles therefor, and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(b)  No person shall throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, household garbage in a publicly maintained receptacle located in a public park within the city. 
(c)  It shall be a defense to prosecution under subsection (b) of this section that, at the time of the depositing of the household garbage, the public receptacle was not marked "City of Weatherford-Not for Household Garbage". 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87; Ord. No. 89-14, 7-11-89) 
Sec. 8-10-8. - Litter in lakes. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere in the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-9. - Distributing handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-10. - Depositing handbills on uninhabited or vacant premises. 
    No person shall place, throw or deposit, in any manner whatsoever, any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private property or premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-11. - Placing handbills in or upon vehicles. 
    No person shall place or deposit, in any manner whatsoever any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-12. - Truck load causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place, as required by state law and subject to all exceptions recognized in state law. A surcharge will be assessed against any load brought to the city disposal area which has not been secured as required by state law. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-13. - Duty of owners and occupants to maintain private property free from litter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or person in control of private property to place, throw, deposit, permit to accumulate, or permit or cause to be placed, thrown or deposited any litter on said private property, or on any gutter adjacent to said private property, or in or on one-half of that portion of an alley adjacent to said property, unless same has been deposited in receptacles for collection in compliance with the requirements of section 8-10-4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-14. - Clearing of litter from private property. 
    The health officer or his designated representative shall notify the owner, occupant or person in control of private property, same to include any gutter adjacent to said private property or one-half of that portion of an alley adjacent to said private property, upon which litter has been thrown, deposited or permitted to accumulate to remove such litter within ten days and to thereafter maintain said private property free of litter. The notice shall be in writing and may be served upon the owner, occupant or person in control of private property by delivering it to him in person or to an adult person at his residence or place of business, or by certified letter, return receipt requested, addressed to such owner, occupant or person in control of private property at his last known mailing address. It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or person in control of private property to fail, neglect, or refuse to properly dispose of litter upon said private property within ten days after notice as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-15. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00, and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof, in which the violation is continued or permitted. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 8-10-16. - Authority to enforce chapter. 
    The health officer or his designated representative, or any police officer of the city shall have authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter when violations occur on private property. Any police officer of the city is authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter when a violation occurs in a "public place" as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 87-31, 11-10-87) 
CHAPTER 11. - WEEDS AND GRASS 

Sec. 8-11-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases and their derivations shall have the following meanings: 
    Health officer. The head of the health and sanitation department or the health officer's authorized representative. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, company, corporation or organization of any kind. 
    Premises. Any lot, tract, plat or parcel of land including the front or side property between the property line and the curb or traveled way, commonly referred to as right-of-way, and the rear or side property between the property line and the center line of an adjacent alley or platted but unopened alleyway or right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 87-60, 10-13-87; Ord. No. 92-4, 2-11-92) 
Sec. 8-11-2. - Growth to certain height prohibited; offenses. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he is an owner, occupant or person in control of occupied or unoccupied premises within the city limits and permits weeds or grass located on the premises to grow to a height greater than 12 inches. 
(b)  It is an exception to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section that the property is being used for the planting, cultivating, harvesting or storage of grains, hay, or plants commonly grown in the vicinity, and the property in question is one or more acres in area. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that the premises have been brought into compliance within ten days from the date of issuance of a citation. 
(d)  The defense to prosecution provided in subsection (b) of this section may not be asserted by a person who, within the preceding one year period has been issued a citation for a violation of subsection (a) of this section which resulted in: 
(1)  Dismissal of the complaint under subsection (b) defense; 
(2)  Dismissal of the complaint by deferred adjudication; or 
(3)  Conviction. 
(e)  Allegation and proof of a culpable mental state is not required for the proof of an offense defined by this section. 
(Ord. No. 87-60, 10-13-87) 
Sec. 8-11-3. - Enforcement. 
    The code enforcement officer or any duly authorized representative of the code enforcement office shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and shall be authorized to issue citations for violations hereof; provided, that where a fire hazard exists by virtue of any violation of this chapter, the provisions of section 8-11-2 of this chapter may be enforced by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 92-4, 2-11-92) 
Sec. 8-11-4. - City removal of weeds; notice required. 
(a)  Upon the failure of the owner, occupant or person in control of premises to comply with section 8-11-2 of this chapter, the city may have the weeds or grass cut and removed from the premises. 
(b)  Before having weeds or grass cut and removed from the premises, the health officer shall notify the owner of the premises to bring the premises into compliance with section 8-11-2 of this chapter within ten days. The notice shall be in writing and may be served upon the owner by handing it to him in person, or by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known mailing address of the owner. If the owner cannot be personally served or the certified letter is returned by the United States Postal Service, notice may be given by publication two times within ten consecutive days in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(c)  The health officer may issue citations for violations of section 8-11-2 of this chapter regardless of whether a notice is issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 87-60, 10-13-87) 
Sec. 8-11-5. - Charges to be levied; lien on property for failure to pay charges. 
(a)  If the city cuts or removes weeds or grass upon the failure of the owner of the premises to comply with the terms of the notice required under section 8-11-4 of this chapter, charges in the amount of the total actual costs incurred by the city in performing said work shall be collected from the owner of the premises. The charges shall be collected by the city's director of finance. If the charges are not paid within 30 days after notice to the property owner that the charges are due, the health officer shall file with the County Clerk of Parker County, Texas, a statement signed by the mayor or the health officer of the total actual cost incurred by the city in cutting and removing weeds or grass from the premises. 
(b)  Upon the filing of the statement under subsection (a) of this section, the city shall have a privileged lien against the property, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, in the amount of the actual costs incurred together with interest at the rate of ten percent per annum on said amount from the date the costs were incurred. 
(c)  For any such expenditures and interest as set in subsection (b) of this section, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure had in the name of the city. The statement filed under subsection (a) of this section, or a certified copy of the statement, shall be prima facie proof of the amount of actual costs incurred by the city. 
(Ord. No. 87-60, 10-13-87) 
Sec. 8-11-6. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00, and such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day, or portion thereof, in which the violation is continued or permitted. 
(Ord. No. 87-60, 10-13-87) 
CHAPTER 12. - RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS 

Sec. 8-12-1. - State and federal rules affirmed. 
    State and federal rules and regulations for public water supply systems shall be affirmed save and except as follows: 
(1)  No connection shall be made to the public water distribution system owned or controlled by the city, which could be used to discharge water to such system from a water transportation device not owned and controlled by the city. 
(2)  Any water from the public water distribution system which is used for cooling or heating purposes in a system not owned or controlled by the city shall only be discharged to the sanitary sewer system or other approved wastewater disposal system. 
(Ord. No. 96-28, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 8-12-2. - Authority to enforce chapter. 
    The code enforcement department of the city is hereby declared the designated representative for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-28, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 8-12-3. - Area of jurisdiction. 
    This chapter shall apply to any and all public water supply systems within any area that the city shall be authorized to serve. 
(Ord. No. 96-28, 10-22-96) 
Sec. 8-12-4. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 for all cases involving public health and sanitation, and such fine shall not exceed $200.00 in all other cases. Each separate day or any portion thereof, during which any violation of this chapter occurs or continues, shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable as provided in this section. The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be deemed or construed to be a permit for, or an approval of, any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. No permit presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter shall be valid, except insofar as the work or use which it authorized is lawful. 
    The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans shall not prevent the city from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said plans and specifications or from preventing construction operations being carried on thereunder when in violation of this chapter or of any other ordinance or from revoking any certificate of approval when issued in error. 
(Ord. No. 96-28, 10-22-96) 
CHAPTER 13. - WATER AND SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM EXTENSION AND ASSESSMENT POLICY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-39,  I-IV, adopted Nov. 9, 1999, did not specifically amend this Code. Hence, inclusion of said ordinance provisions as  8-13-1-8-13-4 was at the discretion of the editor to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 8-13-1. - General. 
(a)  Title. This chapter shall be known as the "Water and Sanitary Sewer System Extension and Assessment Policy Ordinance" of the city. 
(b)  Statement of purpose. The primary purpose for adoption of this chapter is to set forth the requirements to be followed in extending public water and sanitary sewer lines to serve residential subdivisions or groups of residential customers within the city, where subdivision and development occurred prior to the enactment of other ordinances of city which require the installation of water and sewer services as a condition to subdivision and development. For the purposes of this chapter only, a subdivision shall be deemed to be residential in character if 60 percent or more of the customers in the subdivision are residential customers, and groups of customers shall be deemed to be residential in character if 60 percent or more of the customers in the group are residential customers. The city, in the discretion of the utility board and the city council, may choose to apply this chapter in extending public water and/or sanitary sewer lines to serve commercial subdivisions or groups of residential and commercial customers within the city where subdivision and development occurred prior to the enactment of other ordinances of the city which require the installation of water and sewer services as a condition to subdivision and development. The requirements under this chapter are in addition to and specifically exclude provisions and requirements for extension and installation of water and sewer lines in residential subdivisions or commercial development which are covered in the city subdivision ordinance and any applicable provisions of the building code. The city council and utility board reserve the right to refuse to extend water or sanitary sewer system improvements in situations where off-site mains, laterals, extensions, appliances, adjuncts or appurtenances are required to connect the improvements to the existing city water or sewer system which are not assessable under the provisions of the assessment statute. 
(c)  Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases and their derivations shall have the following meanings: 
    Assessment statute means V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 402, subch. D (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code  402.061 et seq.). 
    Benefitted property, means a lot or tract to which water or sewer service is made available under this chapter. 
    City means City of Weatherford, Texas. 
    Cost of improvement includes construction expense, engineering expenses, fiscal fees, and other expenses incidental to the construction of improvements to the water system, sewer system, or both systems in addition to the other costs of the improvements including acquisition of right-of-way or easements. 
    Customer means the owner of a lot, tract or parcel of real property who purchases water or sewer services from the city. 
    Lien means the right to take and sell or hold the property of a debtor as security or payment for a debt. 
    Owner means a person having legal title to the lot, tract or parcel of real property in question. If a particular lot, tract or parcel of real property is owned by more than one co-owners, the owner of such tract for purposes of this chapter shall be all of the owners of undivided interest in the real estate. 
    Potential customer means the owner of a lot, tract or parcel of real property who desires to purchase water or sewer services from the city if the requested extension of water or sewer service is granted. 
    Sewer system improvements means the laying of mains, laterals, and extensions and all appliances and necessary adjuncts required for the sanitary disposal of sewage from the area in which the improvements are made but does not include off-site mains, laterals, and extensions and appliances and adjuncts necessary to connect the improvements to the existing sewer system operated by the municipality. 
    Utility board means the Weatherford Municipal Utility Board of Trustees. 
    Water system improvements means the laying of a water main with gates, tees, crosses, taps, meter boxes, manholes, or extensions, and any other appurtenances required to furnish water for domestic or commercial purposes to the area in which the improvements are constructed but does not include any off-site appurtenances required to connect the improvements to the existing water system operated by the municipality. 
    Any of the terms which are defined in this section shall also bear any meaning ascribed thereto in the annexation statute. 
Sec. 8-13-2. - Project determination. 
(a)  Improvements requested by customer(s). One potential customer or a group of single potential customers may request public water or sanitary sewer lines be extended to serve the property owned by such petitioning potential customers. Any such request must be made in writing and addressed to the director of utilities, and shall state that the petitioner acknowledges that if the extension is made by the city, the benefitted properties will be assessed a portion of the costs of the extension. If a particular benefitted property is owned by more than one co-owner, the number of co-owners necessary to make the request shall be such proportion of such owners of undivided interest as the city may determine, in its reasonable discretion, necessary to act on behalf of all such co-owners. In order for any request to be effective, at least 65 percent of the owners of benefitted properties must submit such a request to the city. Any request by a potential customer expires, and cannot be considered in computing a percentage of requests by owners of benefitted property, 90 days after it is submitted to the director of utilities, unless the required percentage of other requesting owners is received by the director of utilities prior to such expiration date. The percentage will be based on the number of properties which request the extension, compared to the total number of all of the benefitted properties in the area to be served by the request. The director of utilities shall determine the area to be served by the request, which shall be limited to the potential customers who could be connected to the extension from the point of connection of extension to the existing city system to the end of the extension. The end of the extension is the logical termination point, as determined by the director of utilities, beyond the last requesting potential customer. Unless the topography or other engineering conditions dictate otherwise, the end of the extension will be the end of the block or street, which contains potential customers, involved in the request. The area to be served by the request may include an entire subdivision if more than 65 percent of the lots in the subdivision are involved in the request. 
    The letter of request should also include the following items for each potential customer. 
(1)  Name 
(2)  Address 
(3)  Telephone number 
(4)  Lot, block, and addition or on unplatted property, a tract designation per local tax maps, survey name, and abstract number 
(5)  Type and size of service requested 
(6)  Preference of service location as measured from property corner along frontage 
    Upon receipt of requests, the director of utilities will review the request. The utilities department will prepare an estimate of cost for the water and/or the sanitary sewer line extensions. The estimate shall include construction costs and an allowance of 25 percent of the construction cost estimate for engineering, administrative, field survey, and contingency costs. A plan layout of the requested improvements shall accompany the estimate and a list of the benefitted properties for per lot or per service. The estimate and accompanying material shall be returned to the director of utilities for presentation to the utility board. Depending on availability of funds, the utility board will authorize or not authorize the city staff to proceed with the detail construction plans and assessment policy requirements. 
(b)  Improvements proposed by city staff. The city staff can initiate projects to extend public water/or sewer system improvements under the provisions of this chapter when the improvements will provide service to benefitted property and the improvements will enhance the public health and general welfare. In such event, the procedure for estimates of costs, plan layout and presentation to the utility board will be followed. 
Sec. 8-13-3. - Assessment policy. 
(a)  Percentage to be assessed benefitted property. The city council will assess up to nine-tenths of the estimated cost of improvements against the benefitted property and the owners of that property. Where an extension is requested pursuant to section 8-13-2(a). above, the city council will assess 65 percent of the estimated cost of the improvements against the benefitted property and the owners of that property. 
    Any portion of the improvements which are to be included in "impact fee" calculations as providing for future development will not be included in the assessments against the benefitted property, except to the extent determined by the city council to be necessary for fairness and substantial equity in administering the utility system and the impact fee ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Apportionment of assessments. The city shall separately compute the cost of the water or sewer improvements and shall apportion the part of the cost of those improvements that may be assessed against the benefitted property and the owners of the property, among the parcels of the benefitted property and the owners for per lot or per service connection assessment. In determining the service connection assessment for each lot or service connection, the city may assign a higher assessment to connections or potential connections for commercial or other customers which will require larger service line and higher volume service demands. 
    The city has determined that, particularly with respect to residential customers having varied frontages and lot sizes, but similar demands on the respective water or sewer system, the front foot rule would result in injustice or inequality. However, if the peculiar circumstances of any particular improvement indicate that justice or equality would better be suited with the front foot rule, the city may elect in such cases to use the front foot rule. In such cases the city shall assess each parcel of benefitted property according to the number of lineal feet of the parcel that abuts on a public street, irrespective of the location of improvements constructed under this chapter relating to that parcel if the improvements provide water or sewer service to the assessed parcel. The city council shall assess a corner lot based on the shorter side of the lot that abuts on a public street. In the event the city assesses costs on a basis other than the front foot rule, the city council shall adjust the apportionment of costs so as to produce a substantial equality of benefits received and burdens imposed. 
    Any assessments levied pursuant to this chapter will relate to the specific improvements made under the extension of services, and such assessments in one district or unit or service area are no wise related to, or connected with the improvements and assessments in any other unit, district or service area, and, in order to make the specific assessments under this chapter, the amount so assessed for improvements will not in any wise be affected by any fact, assessment, cost or other way connected with the improvements or assessments in any other unit, district or service area. 
(c)  Procedure of assessment. The procedure for legally assessing the benefitted properties and owners shall be as set forth in the assessment statute. Any subsequent revision to the assessment statute will be adhered to from its effective date forward. 
(d)  Liens. 
(1)  Notice of improvements. If the city levies or assesses any of the cost of improvements against the benefitted property, the city will file a notice, signed on behalf of the city by the mayor, with the county clerk of each county in which the assessed property is located. The notice will substantially show that the city has determined by ordinance, resolution, order, directive, or otherwise that water or sewer system improvements are necessary, identify the required improvements by location or otherwise, state that a portion of the cost of the improvements is to be or has been specifically assessed against the benefitted property. One notice may contain any number of systems or improvements. 
It is not necessary that a notice under this section gives details or be sworn to or acknowledged. The city may file the notice at any time. The county clerk with whom the notice is filed shall record the notice in the records of mortgages or deeds of trust and shall index it in the name of the city and in the name or other designation of the water or sewer system to which the notice relates. 
(2)  Amount and interest rate. An assessment against benefitted property under this chapter shall be a lien collectable with interest, cost of collection, and reasonable attorney's fees. The assessment is a first and prior lien on the assessed property and the lien takes effect on the date that a notice of proposed improvements is made as stated in the preceding subsection (d)(1). The lien is superior to any other lien or claim except a state, county, school district, or municipal property tax lien. The assessment is a personal liability and charge against the owners of the assessed property of the date on which the lien takes effect, whether or not the owners are named in a notice, instrument, certificate, or ordinance. The city may make assessments against several parcels of benefitted property in one assessment if the parcels are owned by the same person. The city may jointly assess benefitted property owned jointly by one or more persons. 
When the ordinance is adopted levying the assessment of the costs for improvements against benefitted property, the city council shall prescribe an interest rate to be applied on the assessments not to exceed ten percent a year the "maximum rate". The interest rate shall be not less than the "prime rate" then most currently published the Wall Street Journal plus one percent per annum, not to exceed the maximum rate. In the event the prime rate is not published or not available in the Wall Street Journal, the interest rate shall not be less than the average prime or base rate of interest charged by the three largest banking institutions in Dallas County, Texas which are in place and in effect at the time of the assessment, plus one percent per annum not to exceed the maximum rate. The interest on the liens shall begin after the public improvements are complete and functional and thirty days after invoices have been mailed to all benefitted property owners. 
(e)  Assessing ordinance. Complying with the requirements of the assessment statute, after the declaration for the need for the improvement, engineer's estimate, notices, hearings and determinations by the city council, the city shall adopt an ordinance ("assessment ordinance") providing for the assessments, establishing the rate of interest and terms of payment in accordance with the provisions of the assessment statute and this chapter. 
Sec. 8-13-4. - Payment procedure. 
(a)  Lump sum. The assessed amount can be paid any time prior to 30 days after the invoices are mailed out without interest costs. After that time, a lump sum payment may be made and the payment will be applied first to any interest accumulation. 
(b)  Five payment payout plan. Upon written request, the city will allow a benefitted property owner to divide his assessment into five equal payments, which include the "remaining balance" interest at the rate prescribed by the city council. The first payment to be made within 60 days of the date the invoice was mailed. The subsequent four payments shall be made annually on the anniversary date of the initial payment. 
(c)  Other pay out plans. The city, in its assessment ordinance, may establish other installment payment plans providing for the payment of the assessment and accrued, unpaid interest on a monthly basis over a period of time not to exceed three years. 
(d)  Non-payment provision.
