(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemption herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of any said vehicle while in motion sounds an audible signal or bell, siren or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light from in front of the vehicle. 
(d)  The foregoing provisions shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Code 1962) 
CHAPTER 3. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 10-3-1. - Authority to install traffic-control devices. 
    The chief of police shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under the traffic regulations of the municipality to make effective the provisions of said regulations, and may place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-2. - Specifications for traffic-control devices. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the approved specifications. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the municipality. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of this title shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-3. - Obedience to official traffic-control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with the traffic regulations of the municipality, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-4. - When traffic-control devices required. 
    No provisions of this title for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-5. - Traffic-control signal legend. 
    Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals exhibiting the words "Go", "Caution" or "Stop" or exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time or with arrows, the following colors only shall be used and said terms and light shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green alone or "Go": 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal, except when prohibited herein, may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
b.  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Yellow alone or "Caution" when following the green or "Go" signal: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the red or "Stop" signal will be exhibited immediately and such vehicular traffic shall not enter the intersection when the yellow or "Caution" signal is exhibited. 
b.  Pedestrians facing such signal are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway and any pedestrian then starting to cross shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles. 
c.  Pedestrians facing such signal shall not enter the roadway until the green or "Go" is shown alone unless authorized to do so by a pedestrian "Walk" signal. 
(3)  Red alone or "Stop": 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain standing until green or "Go" is shown alone. 
b.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green or "Go" is shown alone unless authorized so to do by a pedestrian "Walk" signal. 
(4)  Red with green arrow: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing such signal may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow but shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
b.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green or "Go" is shown alone unless authorized so to do by a pedestrian "Walk" signal. 
(5)  In the event an official traffic-control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this chapter shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any such sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-6. - Pedestrian-control signals. 
    Whenever special pedestrian-control signals exhibiting the words "Walk" or "Wait" or "Don't Walk" are in place such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  Walk. Pedestrians facing such a signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way. 
(2)  Wait or don't walk. It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the "Walk" signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety zone while the "Wait" signal is showing. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-7. - Flashing signals. 
    Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(2)  Railroad crossings. This section shall not apply at railroad grade crossings. Conduct of drivers of vehicles approaching railroad grade crossings shall be governed by the rules set forth in chapter 7 of this title. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-8. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking, or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal. 
(b)  No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. 
(c)  This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(d)  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the highway is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-9. - Interference with official traffic-control devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without lawful authority, to attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon or any part thereof. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-10. - Crosswalks and safety zones. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is a particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-11. - Traffic lanes. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(b)  Where such traffic lanes have been marked it shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle within the boundaries of such lane except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparatory to making a lawful turning movement. 
(Code 1962) 
Sec. 10-3-12. - Specifically controlled streets. 
    The traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings heretofore placed or erected by the police department or street department and now in use, as follows, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic, are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be official traffic-control devices; provided that these traffic-control devices are consistent with the "manual and specifications" as approved by the state highway commission or resolutions adopted by the city council. 
TRAFFIC CONTROL FOR THE CITY OF WEATHERFORD

Sec. 10-3-13. - Specifically controlled areas. 
    The traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings placed or erected by the police department or the street department, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic are hereby declared to be the official traffic-control devices at the following described areas: 
    North/south alleyway as platted in Block 35, Carter Addition, between the 200 block of West Weatherford Street and the 200 block of West First Street-Through traffic prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, 3-8-88) 
Sec. 10-3-14. - Penalty. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is a misdemeanor. Every person convicted of a misdemeanor for a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $200.00.

CHAPTER 4. - PARKING REGULATIONS[1]

Sec. 10-4-1. - Standard of time. 
    All hours of time mentioned in this chapter refer to and shall be determined by "Central Standard Time", as commonly known, except, during any future time, any standard of time established or proclaimed by the United States for an area including this city, all such hours shall be determined by such officially proclaimed standard, so long as same remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-2. - Days regulations applicable. 
    The regulations provided for in this chapter are applicable during any hour of the day; however, in parking meter, loading, work and delivery zones, and specific time restricted zones, parking violations shall not be enforced except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., on all days except Saturday, Sunday, federal, state or local holidays unless signed and restricted by ordinance otherwise. Local holidays shall include holidays established or designated by minute order of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-3. - Parking meter zone. 
    The city council may, from time to time, by resolution or minute order define the areas which shall be defined, described and designated as a parking meter zoned area and may provide for the parking meter rates, as well as adopting other parking regulations within the designated parking meter zone. 
    Within the parking meter zone, no person shall park a motor vehicle in any metered space unless he or some other person promptly deposits in the meter, United States coins sufficient to pay for the parking time, and no person shall allow a motor vehicle under his control to remain in a metered space after the time so purchased and indicated by the meter has expired. A "metered space" is defined as the space adjacent to a parking meter. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07; Ord. No. 365-2008-40,  2, 6-24-08) 
Sec. 10-4-4. - Parking meter spaces, loading zones designated. 
(a)  In said parking meter zone, by minute order or resolution, the council is authorized to cause parking spaces, loading zones and restricted parking areas to be designated and maintained. All spaces for parking vehicles shall be laid out and shall be designated by lines or marks on the surface of the street or curbs, where practical, and shall be so laid out that there shall be one parking space for and at each installed parking meter. 
(b)  Loading zones for the loading and unloading of passengers and/or heavy or bulky merchandise, supplies or materials shall be designated and laid out by orange-colored lines or marks on the surface of the street or curb with the words "loading zone" painted thereon. 
(c)  Restricted parking areas where there are no parking meters, shall be designated by appropriate signs either at the curb or other appropriate place in or adjacent to said restricted parking area, said signs to specify the time limit for legal parking within said restricted area. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-5. - Lengths of time and rates charged for parking. 
    The council, in ordering the placement of parking meters, shall specify the length of time a vehicle may be parked in said meter space upon deposit of a specified coin of the United States in said parking meter. Each parking meter shall be so set as to display an indicator and dial showing legal parking upon deposit of appropriate coin of the United States. The parking time allowed by the deposit of said coin shall be clearly indicated on the meter. Each meter shall, by its mechanical device, continue operation from time of depositing the appropriate coin therein until the expiration of that parking time which was secured by said coin deposit. At the end of the legal parking time it will indicate, by mechanical operation and the display of a signal, that the lawful parking period has expired. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-6. - Installation and operation of parking meters. 
    The chief of police or other officer authorized by the council is hereby authorized to install and maintain, or cause to be installed or maintained, parking meters in or on said areas within the parking meter zone as may be authorized and designated by minute order or resolution of the council and said chief of police or other authorized officer shall provide for the regulation, control, operation and maintenance of such parking meters in good workable condition. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-7. - Deposit of coins. 
    When any vehicle shall be parked in any space alongside of or adjacent to which there is located a parking meter, the operator of said vehicle shall immediately, upon entering said parking space, deposit an appropriate coin or coins of the United States in the slot made therefore in said parking meter and the said parking space may then be used by such vehicle during the parking time limit secured by the deposit of said coin. If the said vehicle shall remain parked in any such parking space beyond the parking time limit for which said coins have been deposited, the parking meter shall display a sign or signal showing illegal parking, and in such event said vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this chapter and such parking of a vehicle overtime shall be unlawful and considered a violation of this chapter and the operator shall be subject to the penalty prescribed for a violation of this Code. The display of a sign or signal showing illegal parking at any parking meter while a vehicle is parked in the parking space adjacent to said parking meter shall be prima facie evidence that said vehicle has been parked overtime and beyond a period of time as fixed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-8. - Parking in restricted parking area. 
    When any vehicle is parked in any restricted parking area, the operator of said vehicle may leave said vehicle parked in said restricted area for the length of time specified on the sign or signs designating the lawful time limit of said restricted parking area. If the said vehicle shall remain parked in any such restricted parking area beyond the time limit specified on the sign designating said restricted parking area, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this chapter and such parking of the vehicle shall be considered a violation of this chapter and the operator shall be subject to the penalty herein set forth in this Code.

    City of Weatherford property commonly known as the Weatherford Public Market Property which is bounded by Trinity Street on the north, Fort Worth Street on the south, East Spring Street on the east and an approximate 100-foot  152-foot structure on the west. Maximum time limit: One hour = (60 minutes). 
    It is a defense to prosecution under section 10-4-8 of this chapter that at the time of the commission of the offense, said vehicle was being used in a retail or wholesale area for the sale of produce or produce related items in accordance with duly erected signs permitting same or that at the time of the commission of the offense, no sign restricting parking was posted. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-9. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by police officers of the City of Weatherford Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07; Ord. No. 365-2008-40,  2, 6-24-08)

Editor's note- Ord. No. 365-2008-40,  2, adopted June 24, 2008, repealed  10-4-10, which pertained to illegal stopping, standing or parking and derived from Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07. 
Sec. 10-4-11. - Manner of parking. 
    In addition to complying with such other parking regulations as set forth herein, the operator of any vehicle shall park such vehicle with the front of said vehicle alongside of or next to the parking meter and the entire vehicle within the lines marked on the curb and/or street designating the parking space. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-12. - Unlawful to deface meters. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-13. - Unlawful to deposit slug. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or substitute for the coins of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-14. - Fees to cover regulation and supervision. 
    The United States coins required to be deposited in parking meters as provided herein are charged and collected as fees for police regulation, supervision and inspection to cover the cost of the installation, maintenance, inspection, operation, control and use of parking spaces and parking meters described herein and regulating the parking of vehicles in the parking meter zone herein described. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-15. - Use of loading zones for loading and unloading. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any operator to stand or park a vehicle in a loading zone for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers for a period in excess of two minutes. 
    The use of loading zones for the loading and unloading of materials, supplies and merchandise shall be for the loading and unloading of heavy or bulky merchandise, supplies or materials. As such loading and unloading must be performed in an expeditious manner and no vehicle shall remain in a loading zone for a period of time longer than is necessary to expeditiously load or unload the same. It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any operator to allow a vehicle to remain parked in said loading zone for a period of time longer than is necessary to expeditiously load or unload the same. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 365-2008-40,  2, adopted June 24, 2008, repealed  10-4-16, which pertained to impounding of vehicles and derived from Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07. 
Sec. 10-4-17. - Collection of money from meters. 
    It shall be the duty of the city council to designate some employee of the city to make regular collections of the money deposited in said meters. In this connection, it shall be the duty of such person so designated to pick up the sealed cylinders containing the coins so deposited in the meters, and deliver said cylinders, with the seals unbroken, to the secretary or other official as may be designated and authorized by the city council, as soon as practical after removal from the meter. It shall be the duty of the secretary or other authorized or designated official of the city to break the seals and count the funds and deposit same to the credit of the general fund of the city. The duties prescribed for the officer under the terms of this section shall be in addition to his regular duties. 
    Each person so designated to collect said cylinders from the parking meters shall, as directed by the city council to do so, execute a fiduciary bond in the sum of $1,000.00, payable to the city, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties in collecting and delivering all such monies, which bond shall be executed by a corporate surety which has been duly authorized under the laws of the state to execute such bond. The premium for such bond shall be paid by said city. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-18. - Parking vehicles with trailers, long trucks. 
    It shall hereafter be unlawful for any operator in charge or control of any vehicle which has an overall length of 19 feet or more, or of any vehicle having a trailer attached thereto, to park the same in any parking meter space in the parking meter zone established by this chapter. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply on all days and on all hours both daytime and nighttime. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-19. - Validation of existing facilities. 
    All parking meters, parking meter spaces, loading zones and restricted parking areas presently in existence are hereby expressly validated, approved, authorized and hereby designated as such by the adoption of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-4-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 10-4-21A. - Special activities exception. 
    The city council may, from time to time, on recommendation from the chief of police and in consideration of special conditions, designate certain community activities as exceptions and permit on-street parking in restricted parking areas if said parking restriction signs are covered. 
(Ord. No. 326-2007-92, 12-11-07)
